fields.descriptive_line: Design for woven silk from the 'Leman Album', pencil, pen and ink, watercolour and bodycolour on laid paper, possibly by James Leman, 1736-1739
fields.physical_description:
Design for woven silk from the 'Leman Album', in pencil, pen and ink, watercolour and bodycolour, depicting large red and pink flowers, with centres like a bunch of berries, leaves and two plums climbing up a frame reminiscent of gilded furniture. Above this there is a smaller, semi-circular feature of foliage and pink, rounded fruit against a frame. This smaller component is in the folded part of the design. 

The design is incomplete and has a pencilled part linking the two finished areas. It is also patched in one area probably to show an alteration to the original drawing.
fields.dimensions: Height: 59.7 cm, Width: 28 cm, Height: 23.5 in, Width: 11 in
fields.materials_techniques: Pencil, pen and ink, watercolour and bodycolour on laid paper
fields.public_access_description:
This design is from an album that contains 104 designs for fine woven silk cloth. A constant supply of fashionable new designs from which to create new lines was required, so patternmakers and master weavers like James Leman supplied a wide range of designs for different weavers. The album contains some of his work from the period 1706-1716, as well as five designs from the 1730s, including this one which is from about 1736-1739.

Natalie Rothstein stated in her catalogue Silk Designs of the Eighteenth Century that 'French drawings of the later 1730s show a similar rather heavy style and also make use of ultramarine, as in the fruit here. However, this is possibly an English copy of a French design. It does not appear to be by the same hand'.

James Leman was born in 1688 into a weaving family of Huguenot descent. In 1702 he was apprenticed to his father, Peter, and lived with his family in Stewart Street, Spitalfields in London.
fields.bibliography: Full text of the entry is as follows: '[No inscription] The design is incomplete and has a pencilled part linking the two finished areas. French drawings of the later 1730s show a similar rather heavy style and also make much use of ultramarine, as in the fruit here. However, this is possibly an English copy of a French design. It does not appear to be by the same hand as VS.1. Design patched in one area. 23 1/2" (59.7) x 11" (28) [pl. 112] CT.18279 VS.97'
fields.credit: Purchased with the assistance of The Art Fund and the National Heritage Memorial Fund
fields.history_note:
This is a design from the so-called 'Leman album' which was bought from Vanners Silks Ltd. in 1991. Natalie Rothstein catalogued the designs before the album was bought by the Victoria and Albert Museum. She gave each design a VS number (for Vanners Silks) in her catalogue <u>Silk Designs of the Eighteenth Century</u>. The designs have been subsequently numbered by the Prints, Drawings and Paintings Department, however, a concordance exists.

Historical significance: The designs collected in the album are, with the exception of some fragmentary medieval examples in Italian collections, the earliest silk designs known to exist.
fields.production_note: The following information is taken from Natalie Rothstein, Silk Designs of the Eighteenth Century. Please see the bibliographic reference under 'References' for more details. 'French drawings of the later 1730s show a similar rather heavy style and also make much use of ultramarine, as in the fruit here. However, this is possibly an English copy of a French design. It does not appear to be by the same hand as VS.1.' (E.1861.2-1991). Attribution note: The design is patched in one area probably to show an alteration to the original drawing. Rothstein also stated that this drawing is one of five (E.1861.2-1991 (VS.1), E.1861.55-1991 (VS.97), E.1861.85-1991 (VS.76), E.1861.101-1991 (VS.92), E.1861.105-1991 (VS.96)) 'which fall outside the main body of the Vanners Silks Set. They are all of much later date. This can be seen by comparing them with dated designs in the [Anna Maria] Garthwaite Set [in the Prints, Drawings and Paintings Department at the V&A] and with dated French designs in Paris and Lyon. The choice of motifs, the much greater degree of naturalism and the use in all but VS.76 [E.1861.85-1991] of points rentrésindicate for all of them a date in the 1730s. It is conceivable that some of these drawings are by James Leman who was still alive in the 1730s. The short English inscription on VS.76 [E.1861.85-1991] may be in his hand and the inscription itself, together with the fact that three of the drawings have been squared off for drafting, does seem to indicate that these patterns were woven in England. But the superb design VS.96 [E.1861.105-1991] and to a lesser extent VS.96 [E.1861.85-1991] and VS.92 [E.1861.101-1991], so resemble French designs of the period that they must either be actual French drawings or close copies of them. There can be no doubt that VS.96 [E.1861.105-1991] is French and possibly by Jean Revel himself. It would have been perfectly in accordance with the practice at Spitalfields for Leman to have been in possession of French designs for woven silks: among the group of designs belonging to Garthwaite is a whole series labelled 'French Patterns'. The present five designs [E.1861.2-1991 (VS.1), E.1861.55-1991 (VS.97), E.1861.85-1991 (VS.76), E.1861.101-1991 (VS.92), E.1861.105-1991 (VS.96)] may represent some of Leman's 'French Patterns'.'
